source.name: If Else
source.instructions:
Drag the appropriate code blocks into the box below. Your program should check to see if a number is even and print "Even". If the number is odd, then print "Odd". Assume the variable `x` represents the number to be tested.

Remember to indent your code!
source.guidance:
Here is the correct answer:

```java
if(x % 2 == 0)
    {System.out.print("Even");}
else
    {System.out.print("Odd");}
```

Here is why the other options are incorrect:

* `if x % 2 = 0` - The equality operator (`==`) is not used.
* `if x / 2 == 0` - The `/` operator is division. To be even, there can be no remainder. The modulo operator (`%`) must be used instead.
* `System.out.print(Even);` - The quotation marks are missing. Without them, Java will try to print the variable `Even`, which has not been declared. 
* `System.out.print(Odd);` - The quotation marks are missing. Without them, Java will try to print the variable `Odd`, which has not been declared.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT construct an if else statement

source.name: If Statements
source.instructions:
Select all of the statements below that are true with regards to if statements. 

**Hint:** There is more than one correct answer.

answers.answer: If statements only ask if a boolean expression is true.
If statements will perform a set of actions if the boolean expression is false.
If statements provide the most precision of all the conditional statements.
If statements are the simplest of all the conditionals.

source.guidance:
The correct answers are:

```
If statements only ask if a boolean expression is true.

If statements are the simplest of all the conditionals.
```

If statements can only ask if a boolean expression is true. An else statement takes into account a false boolean expression.

If statements are the simplest because they ignore when a boolean expression is false, and they do not ask subsequent boolean expressions.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand the characteristics of an if statement

source.name: Make a Triangle
source.instructions: Construct a program by drag&dropping and reordering lines from the left to the right. You can change the loop header () by clicking them. The constructed program should draw a triangle like shown below. Hint: You need to indent the lines of code within the loop by dragging the blocks slightly to the right. We'll talk about this next.
source.initial:
REPEAT $$toggle::2::3::4$$ TIMES
forward(100)
left(120)
ENDREPEAT
source.guidance:
The loop header is setting up how many times code is repeated. In the case of a triangle, it makes sense to repeat 3 times - one for each side.

```
REPEAT 3 TIMES
  forward(100)
  left(120)
ENDREPEAT
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT... define a loop header

source.name: Make a Square
source.instructions: Construct a program by drag&dropping and reordering lines from the left to the right. You can change the loop header () by clicking them. The constructed program should draw a square like shown below. Be sure to indent the loop body by dragging repeated blocks slightly to the right.
source.initial:
REPEAT $$toggle::2::3::4$$ TIMES
forward(100)
left(90)
ENDREPEAT
source.guidance:
The loop header is setting up how many times code is repeated. In the case of a square, it makes sense to repeat 4 times - one for each side.

The loop body are the lines to be repeated, in this case the blocks instructing the turtle to turn and step forward.

```
REPEAT 4 TIMES
  forward(100)
  left(90)
ENDREPEAT
```

source.name: Division
source.instructions: Which of the following statements about division in Java is **FALSE**?

answers.answer: You can use the division operator with `int`s
You will get the same result from the division operator using `int`s and `double`s
You can use the division operator with `double`s
You are not allowed to divide by 0

source.guidance: `int`s and `double`s behave differently with the division operator. Using `double` will result in a decimal where `int` will result in a whole number with the decimal removed. This means that `10/3` is either `3.3333...` or `3` based on data types.

source.name: Modulo
source.instructions: What does modulo (`%`) do?

answers.answer: Determines if a number is even or odd
Determines the percentage of two numbers
Returns the remainder after division is performed

source.guidance: Modulo is the remainder after division is performed. So division is a part of modulo, but modulo is not division. Modulo can be used to determine if a number is even or odd, but modulo can do more than that. Finally, the `%` is used with modulo, but modulo does not deal with percentages.

source.name: Short Circuiting
source.instructions: Use the dropdown menus to complete the text below.
source.text:
## Or Operator
When using the `||` operator, Java checks to see if the first boolean expression is <<<true>>>. If it is <<<true>>>, Java returns <<<true>>> and ignores the second boolean expression.

## And Operator
When using the `&&` operator, Java checks to see if the first boolean expression is <<<false>>>. If it is <<<false>>>, Java returns <<<false>>> and ignores the second boolean expression.
source.guidance:
If the first boolean expression for the `||` operator is true, then the entire thing is true. The second boolean expression is ignored.

If the first boolean expression for the `&&` operator is false, then the entire thing is false. The second boolean expression is ignored.

source.name: Evaluating Expressions
source.instructions:
Using your knowledge of boolean operators, choose the best answer about evaluating the below:

`( 5 != 4 ) && ( 3 > 0 ) && ( ! 2 == 3 ) || #unknown condition#`

answers.answer: The answer if `false` - Java short circuits because you have a `false` condition with an `&&` operator
The answer if `true` - Java short circuits because you have a `true` condition with an `||` operator
There is not enough information - we would need to know the "unknown condition"

source.guidance: Because the first three conditions evaluate as true, when combined with `&&` evaluates as true. When you reach the `||` operator you then have `true || #unknown condition#`. Java short circuits and evaluates the entire line as `true` without ever evaluating the #unknown condition#.

source.name: Boolean Operators
source.instructions:
Determine if the code below returns true or false.

`(7 >= 7) && (true || 99 < 1) || ! (3 > 5 && 7 < 10) && 2 != 4`
source.guidance:
First, start by evaluating the expressions in the parentheses.

`( 7 >= 7)` returns true.
`(true || 99 < 1)` returns true
`! (3 > 5 && 7 < 10)` returns true
`2 != 4` returns true
So the boolean expression is now `true && true || true && true`, which returns true.

source.name: If Else Syntax
source.instructions:
Which of the following are true about using an if-else? 

*Hint:* There is more than one right answer.

answers.answer: Indentation effects how the code runs
You should use curly braces `{}` after both the `if` condition and the `else` keyword to group code that is conditionally executed
The `else` condition does not have another boolean expression
There should be empty parentheses `()` after the `else` keyword

source.guidance:
Java uses curly braces to group code commands. While indention is helpful, it does not effect how the program runs. Instead, you need to use curly braces to tell Java what code runs in both the true condition (after the `if`) and the false condition (after the `else`).

Additionally, because `else` refers to the `if`, it does not need its own boolean expression. Nor does it need parentheses.

source.name: Switch Case or If Else?
source.instructions: Which of the following would be most appropriate for a `switch` statement?

answers.answer: Providing different types information about a caller's bank account (or re-directing the call) based on the number they pressed on their keypad
Generating the overall and category (male under 20, male over 50, female under 20, female over 50, etc) winners of a 5k race
Using a car's mileage and service history to list what work needs to be done

source.guidance:
Generating race winners requires comparing unknown times and for categories you will need a compound conditional -- so you need `if else`.

Similarly, a car's milage is going to fall into a range. Additionally, you will need to check against variables to see if the service has been done -- so you need `if else`.

A `switch` would work well in the phone example since the user can only press 10 discrete buttons with constant values.

source.name: For Loop Headers
source.instructions:
Which of the following `for` loop headers will loop **exactly** 100 times? Ignore the value of the iterating variable and focus on the **number of times** the loop body will be executed.

**Note:** There may be more than one correct answer.
source.guidance:
Only choices #1 and #4 are correct because they are both executed **exactly** 100 times. `for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)` goes from 0 to 99 and `for (int i = 1; i <= 100; i++)` goes from 1 to 100. Both of those ranges include 100 iterations.

`for (int i = 0; i <= 100; i++)` goes from 0 to 100 which is a total of 101 iterations.

`for (int i = 1; i < 100; i++)` goes from 1 to 99 which is only 99 iterations.

source.name: While vs. For Loops
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks below with either `while` or `for`.
source.text:
A <<<while>>> loop usually contains a boolean expression(s) in its header and nothing else.
A <<<for>>> loop contains a header that specifies where an iterator variable starts, where it ends, and how it is changed per iteration.
A <<<for>>> loop is better if a command needs to be executed a certain number of times.
A counting variable needs to be declared and initialized before a <<<while>>> loop can be executed properly.
source.guidance: One big difference between a `while` loop and a `for` loop is that a `while` loop only contains a boolean expression(s) within its header. That means a counting variable must be declared and initialized before a `while` loop can be used properly. On the other hand, the header of a `for` loop contains an iterator variable which helps to determine how many times the `for` loop will run.

source.name: For Loop to While Loop
Break Statement Purpose
source.instructions: What purpose does the `break` statement serve?

answers.answer: The `break` statement is used to pause a program so that it can run at a later time.
The `break` statement is required in every `while` loop to separate sections of code.
The `break` statement is used to end a program.
The `break` statement is used to stop and exit a loop.

source.guidance: The `break` statement is used to stop and exit a loop **not** a program. `break` statements are often used to prevent situations where an infinite loop might be involved; however, `break` statements are not always required.

source.name: While Loop Syntax
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks below so that the `while` loop prints `Java` **10** times.
source.guidance: The counting variable that is being used in the code is called `count`. If `count` is initialized to `0`, then **ten iterations** will cause it to stop at `9`. Thus, `count < 10` is the correct loop header. `count = count + 1` does the same  thing as `count++` and will increment the counting variable by `1` after during each iterations.

source.name: Break Statement Syntax
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks such that the loop will **stop and exit** after it has run **100** times.
source.guidance: `total` is the counting variable that is used in the code above. To increment `total` so that it iterates **100 times**, `total = total + 1` is needed. Since `total` starts at `0` and we want it to iterate 100 times before stopping, we will insert a `break` statement to stop the loop once `total > 99` becomes true. The range from `0` through `99` is a total of exactly 100 iterations.

source.name: Nested Loops
source.instructions: Which definition best describes a nested loop?

answers.answer: A nested loop is when you have two loops that run one after the other.
A nested loop is when you have a `while` loop and a `for` loop in the same program.
A nested loop is when a loop exists inside another loop.
A nested loop is when you have more than one loop in your program.

source.guidance: By definition, a **nested loop** is when one loop exists inside another loop. There are are restrictions on the type of loop that can be nested nor the number of nested loops that can be used (though it is rare to implement more than two nested loops). Thus, a `for` loop can be nested in another `for` loop and a `while` loop can be nested inside another `while` loop. In addition, a `for` loop can be nested inside a `while` loop and vice versa.

source.name: ArrayList or Array?
source.instructions: Fill out the following statements with either `ArrayList` or `Array` depending on whether each statement is true to one or the other.
source.text:
1. Can be initialized by adding elements into curly braces `{}`: <<<Array>>>
2. Can add or remove elements after being created: <<<ArrayList>>>
3. Can change the order of elements without modifying existing elements: <<<ArrayList>>>
4. Can use `length` to determine the number of elements: <<<Array>>>
source.guidance:
Although it is possible to initialize elements at the start, arrays are **static** so adding or removing elements *after* initialization is not possible. On the other hand, ArrayLists are **dynamic** so it is possible to add, remove, and reorder elements. Arrays use `length` while ArrayLists use `size()` to determine the number of existing elements.

**Solution:**
1. Array
2. ArrayList
3. ArrayList
4. Array

source.name: file basics reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Why is it preferable to use `BufferedWriter` as opposed to just `FileWriter`?

answers.answer: `BufferedWriter` writes to memory, which is faster than writing directly to disk.
`FileWriter` is no longer supported by Java.
`BufferedWriter` writes directly to disk, which is faster than writing to memory.
There is no class called `FileWriter` in Java.

source.guidance: Remember, reading and writing to memory is much faster than reading or writing to disk. So using `BufferedWriter` will be faster than `FileWriter` because `BufferedWriter` writes to memory while `FileWriter` writes to disk.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain why buffers are useful

source.name: appending to a file reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks below with words from the dropdown menu.
source.text:
<<<Writing>>> to a file will erase its contents before adding the string.
<<<Appending>>> to a file will keep its contents and add the string at the end.
source.guidance:
**Writing** to a file will overwrite it. That means all existing content will be replaced with the new content.
**Appending** to a file keeps the existing content and adds the new content at the end of the file.

Select the true statement about reading files in Java.

The `readLine` method reads the entire file at once.
The `read` method reads from the file until it encounters a newline character.

source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define what the readLine method does

source.name: reading question file iteration
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Why do the examples on this page use a while loop instead of a for loop?

answers.answer: We want to iteration until a condition is met (the end of the file) as opposed to iterating a specific number of times.
Java throws an error when reading a file with a for loop.
For loops are slower than while loops.

source.guidance:
The correct answer is: 

```
You want to iteration until a condition is met (the end of the file) as opposed to iterating a specific number of times.
```

We do not know how many lines of text there are in a file. A for loop is not a good choice because it runs a specified number of times. Instead, use a while loop to test for the end of the file. This way your loop runs the correct amount of iterations.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain why a while loop is preferable to a for loop when iterating over a file

source.name: files lab question 1
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

Why does the code above say `System.out.println(text.get(0))` instead of `System.out.println(text)`?

answers.answer: The variable `text` is an ArrayList of strings. If you print `text`, it will print the entirety of the list — including square brackets. Printing `text.get(0)` will print just the text, no square brackets.
Both `System.out.println(text.get(0))` and `System.out.println(text)` print the same thing.
Text files require `System.out.println(text.get(0))` while CSV files require `System.out.println(text)`.

source.guidance: The variable `text` is an ArrayList of strings. If you print `text`, it will print the entirety of the list — including square brackets. Printing `text.get(0)` will print just the first element in the ArrayList, no square brackets. If you want the text, print the string inside the list, not the list itself.

source.name: Method Terminologies
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks below with the correct method terminologies.
source.text:
* <<<public>>> - Determines the visibility of the method.
* <<<static>>> - Determines the association of the method.
* <<<void>>> - Determines the return value of the method.

source.guidance: Generally speaking, methods typically start with the following keywords: `public`, `static`, and `void`. source.name: Local & Global Variables
source.instructions: Determine whether each statement below is `true` or `false`.
source.text:
1. Only static methods can access static global variables: <<<true>>>
1. Local variables can be accessed by other methods as long as those methods are static: <<<false>>>
1. A local and global variable cannot be declared with the same name or the compiler will fail: <<<false>>>
1. Global parameters can be declared as method parameters: <<<true>>>
source.guidance:
**Explanation:**
1. **true**: If global variables are not declared as `static`, they cannot be accessed by static methods.
1. **false**: Local variables are exclusive to the methods they are declared in. They cannot be accessed anywhere else.
1. **false**: Declared local and global variables are considered to be separate variables. This means they do not affect each other and are allowed in Java.
1. **true**: Method parameters are similar to local variables; they are both declared within a method. This separates them from global variables which means it is possible to declare parameters that share the same name as the global variables.

source.name: The contains() Method
source.instructions: Select **all** of the statements that are true about the `contains()` method and strings.

answers.answer: `contains()` returns an index when a word is present in a string
`contains()` will return `false` if a word is found but in a different case (uppercase vs. lowercase)
`contains()` will return `true` if a word is found in a string even if one is lowercase and the other is uppercase

source.guidance: The `contains()` method will return a boolean value (`true` or `false`). The `contains()` method is also case sensitive. That means the characters and case must match. If one is uppercase and the other is lowercase, `contains()` will return `true`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT summarize how the contains() method works with strings

source.name: The substring() method
source.guidance: The `contains()` method has start and stop index values. The start index value is inclusive, meaning this value is a part of the substring. The stop index value is exclusive, meaning that this value will not be part of the substring. Since the code reads `String mySlice = myString.substring(3, 8);`, the substring will include all characters from indices 3 to 7, which is `"vin a"`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the result of a substring() method

source.name: Escape Characters
source.instructions: Select **all** of the ways to correctly print the contraction (`It's`) inside a string declaration.
source.guidance:
There are two possible ways to make a contraction such as `It's` inside a string.
1) Use double quotation marks for the string declaration and a single quote `'` for the contraction. `String myString = "It's my birthday today!";`
2) Use double quotation marks for the string declaration and the escape character `\'` for the contraction. `myString = "It\'s my birthday today!"`

**Note** that you cannot use single quotes `'` to declare strings. Single quotes can only be used for characters typed as `char`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT use quotes inside quotes

source.guidance:
Simply using the `return` or `enter` keys will not produce a newline in Java. You can either use `System.out.println()` or the escape character `\n` to create the newline character. 

**Note** that `\t` creates white spaces similar to when the `tab` key is pressed. It is not the same as a newline character.

source.name: The replace() Method
source.instructions: Assume you have the code `String myString = "The cat in the hat";`. Which of the following code snippets below **will not** make any changes to `myString`?
source.guidance:
In order for the `replace()` method to return a **changed** string, you need to specify a string parameter that actually exists in the original string. `The`, `cat`, and white space (`" "`) all exist in the original string. The only parameter that **does not** exist is `Hat`, therefore, the system will not return a string that is different.

**Solution:**
`myString.replace("Hat", "Bat")`
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT use the replace() method to return changed strings

source.name: The startsWith() Method
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks below with the appropriate responses.
source.text:
The `startsWith()` method can contain up to <<<2>>> parameters.
The first parameter is <<<mandatory>>>.
The second parameter is <<<optional>>>.
source.guidance: The `startsWith()` method has two parameters. The first parameter is required to tell the system what string to look for. The second parameter is optional, which tells the system what **index** to start at. If there is no second parameter, the system will start at index `0` by default.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT distinguish between required and optional parameters

source.name: The indexOf() Method
source.instructions:
Assume that you have two strings, `originalString` and `searchTerm`. Rearrange the code blocks below to test if `searchTerm` is found in `originalString`. If true, print the message `"I found it!"`. **Remember to indent** any command(s) that is associated with a conditional statement or you will not receive credit for your work!

**Hint:** not all of the code blocks will be used.
source.guidance:
Here are the steps to constructing the correct conditional statement:
1) Start with a conditional.
```java
if
```
2) Add the string that is being searched in parentheses.
```java
if (originalString)
```
3) Attach the `indexOf()` method.
```java
if (originalString.indexOf())
```
4) Use `searchTerm` as the parameter for `indexOf()`.
```java
if (originalString.indexOf(searchTerm))
```
5) If `searchTerm` is not found, it will return `-1`. So any number that is not `-1` means that `searchTerm` has been found.
```java
if ((originalString.indexOf(searchTerm)) != -1) {
```
6) Finally, add the `print` statement.
```java
if ((originalString.indexOf(searchTerm)) != -1) {
  System.out.println("I found it!");
}
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT use the indexOf() method in a conditional

source.name: toUpperCase() & toLowerCase()
source.instructions: If strings are **immutable**, then why are methods such as `toUpperCase()` and `toLowerCase()` able to return strings that look different from the original?

answers.answer: Some methods such as `toUpperCase()` and `toLowerCase()` are exceptions to the rule and can directly modify strings.
`toUpperCase()` and `toLowerCase()` delete the original string and replaces it with a modified string.
If the strings have the exact same characters, then `toUpperCase()` and `toLowerCase()` are able to modify the strings.
`toUpperCase()` and `toLowerCase()` do not actually modify the strings directly; they create a copy of the original string and returns that copied string modified.

source.guidance: `toUpperCase()` and `toLowerCase()` are not exceptions to the rule that strings are **immutable**. The methods only create a copy of the original string and all of the modifications happen to the copied version, not the original.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand how methods do not violate the immutability of strings

source.name: String Methods
source.instructions:

* **After:** `THE BROWN CAT JUMPS OVER THE LAZY FOX`

Which two string methods would you use to change the text from **Before** to **After**?
source.guidance: `trim()` only removes leading and trailing white spaces and `toLowerCase()` only converts the characters to their lowercase version. Both of these methods are not helpful in modifying the string in the way that we are looking for. Only `replace()` and `toUpperCase()` will work because `replace()` can modify `dog` to `cat` (note that case is irrelevant in this situation) and `toUpperCase()` will capitalize all of the characters, which is exactly what we want.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recognize which string methods are needed to produce a given output

source.name: Comparing New & Literal Strings
source.guidance:
All of the strings contain the same characters; however, one of them is created using the direct string literal method and two of them are created using the `new` method. As long as the strings contain the same characters, the `equals()` method will always return `true`. On the other hand, `==` can only be used to compare direct string literals, which we only have one of. Thus, you cannot compare any of the strings mentioned using `==` because they will return `false`.

**Solution:**
`System.out.println(string1 == string2);` and `System.out.println(string2== string3);`
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT compare strings using == and equals()

source.name: Lexicographical Order
source.instructions:
Given the following strings:
`45`, `5`, `bob`, `Bob`, and `b`.

Which of the following order is **correct** if Java sorts the strings **lexicographically**?
source.guidance:
If you follow the *precedence* rule, `empty strings < numbers < uppercase letters < lowercase letters`, you'll be able to determine the order of the strings.

First, there are no empty strings, which means the first two strings must be either `45` or `5`. Remember that Java checks characters from left to right and since `4` comes before `5`, `45` is considered to be ordered before `5`.

Second, there is only one uppercase string, `Bob`, so `Bob` will be next in the order.

Last, `bob` and `b` are left. Since `b` has fewer characters, `b` will come before `bob` just like how it will in the dictionary.

**Solution:**
```java
45 
5
Bob
b 
bob
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT compare strings using compareTo()

source.name: The valueOf() Method
source.instructions: What is the purpose of the `valueOf()` method?

answers.answer: To split strings into individual characters separated by commas.
To convert other data types to strings.

source.guidance: By default, the `valueOf()` method only **converts other types of data into strings**. Though it can be helpful in combining converted strings together, it does not do so directly.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain the purpose of the valueOf() method

source.name: Using the concat() Method
source.guidance:
**Guide:**
* `System.out.println("apple" + " banana")` ---> `apple banana`
* `System.out.println(a.concat(" " + b))` ---> `apple  banana`
* `System.out.println(" durian" + " apple")` ---> ` durian apple`
* `System.out.println(d.concat(a))` ---> ` durian apple`
* `System.out.println("cherry" + d)` ---> `cherry durian `
* `System.out.println(c.concat(d))` ---> `cherry  durian `
* `System.out.println(b + "banana")` ---> `banana banana`
* `System.out.println(b.concat(b))` ---> `banana banana `

**Solution:**
If you go through and make note of all of the white spaces, you should notice that only `System.out.println(" durian" + " apple")` & `System.out.println(d.concat(a))` produce the exact same results.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT determine string equality using the `concat()` method

source.guidance: The `charAt()` method returns a character at a particular index in a string. Since we have  the iterating variable `i` that takes on the index number of the string from `0` through its length, `ch` will take on each **character** of the string.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT determine the purpose of the charAt() method

source.name: String Properties
source.instructions: All of the following are true regarding strings **except**:

answers.answer: String characters can be manipulated using the `charAt()` method.
You can use the `length()` method to determine how many characters are in a string.
String indices represent the location at which each string character is located.

source.guidance: All of the options are true with the exception of `String characters can be manipulated using the charAt() method.`. By default, strings are *immutable*, meaning they cannot be manipulated once they are created. They can, however, be overwritten or replaced completely. The `charAt()` only returns a character at a particular index. You cannot use it to manipulate string characters.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT determine the properties of strings

source.name: Changing to Upper or Lowercase

answers.answer: `Character.toUpperCase(ch)` converts **all** characters in the *original* string to uppercase.
`Character.toUpperCase(ch)` converts **lowercase** characters in the *original* string to uppercase.
`Character.toUpperCase(ch)` checks to see if **all** characters in the *original* string are uppercase.
`Character.toUpperCase(ch)` checks to see if **all** characters in the *modified* string are uppercase.

source.guidance: `Character.toUpperCase(ch)` doesn't check to see if a character is uppercase; instead, it **converts** the character to its uppercase form. Remember that the conditional `if (Character.isLowerCase(ch))` precedes `Character.toUpperCase(ch)`, so it will only convert characters to uppercase if those characters are originally lowercase.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT determine the purpose of the toUpperCase() method

source.name: == vs. equals() for Characters
source.instructions: Why is the `==` operator used over the `equals()` method when checking to see if specific **characters** are in a string?

answers.answer: Both the `==` operator and `equals()` method will work but `==` is faster.
The `equals()` method will only work for one character, not multiple.
The `equals()` method is a string method and will not work with characters.
The `==` operator can check for both uppercase and lowercase, but `equals()` can't.

source.guidance: Since characters and strings are technically different data types, some string methods such as `equals()` are not compatible with characters. Thus, only the `==` operator can be used in this case.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between == and equals()

source.name: reading question what is recursion
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Under what circumstances does it make sense to use recursion?

answers.answer: Recursion works best when the solution is self-similar
Recursion can be used at any time
Recursion is too hard; avoid it at all costs
Recursion only works with mathematical concepts like factorial and the Fibonacci sequence

source.guidance: Recursion works best when the solution is self-similar. That is, when the problem is broken down into smaller parts, and the smaller parts are a variation of the large problem.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify when recursion can be used

source.name: recursion formative assessment 1
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Rearrange the code blocks below to create a recursive function that finds the sum of `n` integers. For example, `findFum(5)` would add up the numbers 0 to 5. **Note**, not all of the blocks will be used.
source.guidance: Start off with the function header. The next line of code is the base case `if (n == 0)`. Recursive functions return values, they do not print them. Ignore the code block that says `print(0);`, and use `return 0;`. Next is the else statement. There are two incorrect blocks for the recursive case. First, ignore the code block that says `return(n - findSum(n-1));`. The function should find the sum, but this code block is subtracting from `n`. Also, the recursive function call should move `n` closer to the base case. Since the base case is 0, `n` should get smaller. Use the code block that says, `return(n + findSum(n-1));`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create a recursive function to find the sum

source.name: formative assessment 2 recursion
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Assume you want to write a recursive function that multiplies each element in a list by the number 5. What should the base case be?

answers.answer: When the length of the list is 1
When the length of the list is 0
When the list is equal to 1
When the list is equal to 0

source.guidance: The program should keep recursing until the **length** of the list is 1. A length of 1 means there is only one element left in the list. There is no reason to keep calling the function when once the list is empty.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the base case for a recursive function

source.name: reading question base case
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

What is the purpose of the base case in recursion?

answers.answer: When true, the base case stops the recursive calls and returns a value.
The base case tells the function to call itself.
The base case is another name for recursion.
The base case is the name of the recursive function.

source.guidance: When true, the base case stops the recursive calls and returns a value. In the example of factorial, the base case is when `n` is less than or equal to 1. The function returns `1` and the long line of multiplication happens.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define the base case in recursion
